person_221.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
person_221.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_039.name: JohnWoodward
person_039.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

person_222.name: JethroTull
person_222.description: Agriculturist from Berkshire who who developed new agricultual implements such as the horse-drawn seed drill and hoe.

person_022.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
person_022.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

person_223.name: Michel Lullin deChateauvieux
person_223.description: Genevan patrician, agronomist, and experimenter on agriculture, known for the design of many agricultural inplements.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_348.name: JanIngenhousz
person_348.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

person_040.name: Jean HenriHassenfratz
person_040.description: First Professor of Physics at the École polytechnique, Paris, and mine inspector.

person_227.name: JeanSenebier
person_227.description: Genevan naturalist; pioneer in field of photosynthesis.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_228.name: JohnEvelyn
person_228.description: Writer, landowner, gardener, courtier, diarist, minor government official and a  founding Fellow of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

person_229.name: SamuelHartlib
person_229.description: Born in Elbing (then in Royal (East) Prussia, now in Poland) of a Polish father and English mother, he moved to England in the late 1620s. Hartlib became a major intellectual figure and his 'circle' was one of the major pre-existing groups that helped form the Royal Society of London.

person_230.name: EdwardLisle
person_230.description: Barrister of Moyles Court, Hampshire, who contributed significantly to Observations in Husbandry (1757) which his son published posthumously.

person_231.name: JosephBlack
person_231.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

person_068.name: SmithsonTennant
person_068.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident on France. FRSL.

person_237.name: John SoutheySomerville
person_237.description: A cousin of Robert Southey, he became the 15th Lord Somerville in 1796 and later served as a Scottish representative peer. President of the Board of Agriculture (1798-1800), agriculturalist, and breeder of sheep, Davy fished on his estate near Melrose.

person_020.name: NehemiahGrew
person_020.description: English plant anatomist and physiologist, known as the 'Father of Plant Anatomy'. FRSL.

person_247.name: CarlLinnaeus
person_247.description: Professor of Physic and Botany at Uppsala University. Developed the modern system of taxonomic classification. ForMemFRSL.

person_238.name: PatrickBlair
person_238.description: Scottish surgeon, anatomist and botanist. He joined the 1715 Jacobite rebellion for which he was sentenced to death, but following appeals from various Fellows of the Royal Society of London, he was reprieved. FRSL.

person_239.name: RichardBradley
person_239.description: Professor of Botany at the University of Cambridge. FRSL.

person_021.name: StephenHales
person_021.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

person_372.name: FrancisHome
person_372.description: Physician and Professor of Materia Medica at the University of Edinburgh, 1768-1798.

person_024.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
person_024.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

person_240.name: ErasmusDarwin
person_240.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

person_241.name: Johann FriedrichBlumenbach
person_241.description: Professor of Medicine at Göttingen University. Race theorist who applied comparative anatomy to classification of human races. ForMemRSL.

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_048.name: Nicolas-Théodore deSaussure
person_048.description: Swiss chemist and student of plant physiology who made seminal advances in phytochemistry. ForMemRSL.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_244.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
person_244.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_044.name: ArthurYoung
person_044.description: Agricultural writer and Secretary to the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.

person_041.name: JohnBillingsley
person_041.description: Wrote the Somerset volume for the Board of Agriculture county surveys. A founder of the Bath and West of England Society of which Davy was elected an honorary member in 1804.

person_047.name: Robert WIlliamesVaughan
person_047.description: Welsh landowner, second baronet and Tory MP for Merioneth, 1792-1836. Davy seems to have stayed with him in the summer of 1805.

person_046.name: JamesCooke
person_046.description: Cooke or Cook. Anglican minister of Ardwick (near Manchester). Author of Drill Husbandry Perfected.

person_377.name: JohnMayow
person_377.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

person_051.name: JohnPringle
person_051.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

person_053.name: RichardWatson
person_053.description: Professor of Chemisty at Cambridge University, 1764-1773 and Bishop of Llandaff , 1782-1816. FRSL

person_052.name: GeorgePearson
person_052.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

person_054.name: Charles WilliamBury
person_054.description: Irish landowner and politician, 1st Earl of Charleville from 1806. Was connected to both the Royal Institution and the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.

person_055.name: ThomasDundas
person_055.description: Scottish-born politician and Whig MP, created (1794) first Baron Dundas of Aske. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution and an Ordinary Member of the Board of Agriculture, he was a landowner, owning Loftus alum works. FRSL.

person_056.name: WilliamMontagu
person_056.description: From 1788 fifth Duke of Manchester. Army officer, Ordinary Member of the Board of Agriculture and later Governor of Jamacia. Davy cited his agricultural work in Elements of Agricultural Chemistry

person_105.name: ThomasPoole
person_105.description: Tanner based in Nether Stowey, philanthropist and essayist; a friend of Davy and Coleridge.

person_845.name: John ThomasStanley
person_845.description: A British landowner and amateur scienticist, in 1789 he made a celebrated voyage to the Faroe Islands and Iceland with James Wright, Isaac Benners and John Baine, including the climbing of Mount Hekla. In the same year he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.

person_253.name: George HowlandBeaumont
person_253.description: From 1762, 7th Baronet of Colerton Hall, Leicestershire. Landowner, politician and landscape painter; patron of artists and poets including Wordsworth and Coleridge. A subscriber to the Royal Institution.

person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_255.name: JohnWalker
person_255.description: Professor of Natural History at Edinburgh University. Served as Moderator of the Church of Scotland during 1790.

person_163.name: Thomas CharlesHope
person_163.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_057.name: John BakerHolroyd
person_057.description: Independent-minded MP; from 1802 1st Baron Sheffield and from 1816 1st Earl of Sheffield. President of the Board of Agriculture, 1802-1806. During autumn 1803 Davy stayed with him for three weeks at his Sussex seat, Sheffield Place. FRSL.

person_149.name: CharlesHatchett
person_149.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

place_028.name: Berkshire
place_028.description: Berkshire is a county in south-east England.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_286.name: Leicestershire
place_286.description: A county in the East Midlands of England.

place_287.name: Yorkshire
place_287.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

place_288.name: Doncaster
place_288.description: A city in South Yorkshire, England.

place_290.name: Dudley
place_290.description: A market town in the West Midlands, England.

place_291.name: Lewes
place_291.description: The county town of East Sussex, England.

place_370.name: Rowley Hills
place_370.description: A range of hills in the West Midlands, England.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_294.name: Bagshot Heath
place_294.description: An area of wet and dry heath, bog, and unimproved grassland in Surrey, England.

place_438.name: Chalkhill
place_438.description: Lewes is the county town of Sussex, built into a gap of the chalk hills of the South Downs.

place_296.name: Crimea
place_296.description: A peninsula in Eastern Europe, on the northern coast of the Black Sea. The largest city is Sevastopol.

place_297.name: Herefordshire
place_297.description: A county in the West Midlands, England.

place_298.name: Hereford
place_298.description: The county town of Herefordshire, England.

place_299.name: Truro
place_299.description: The county town of Cornwall, England.

place_300.name: Wiltshire
place_300.description: A county in south-western England. The county town is Trowbridge.

place_301.name: County Antrim
place_301.description: A county in north-eastern Northern Ireland.

place_302.name: Nether Stowey
place_302.description: A village in Somerset, home of the tanner Thomas Poole and formerly Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

place_084.name: East Lothian
place_084.description: A district in Scotland with Haddington as its capital.

place_435.name: Sheffield
place_435.description: A famous park in Uckfield, East Sussex.

place_017.name: Roehampton
place_017.description: Roehampton is an area in south-west London.

place_437.name: Northern Ireland
place_437.description: Northern Ireland consists of six counties to the north-east of the island, not including the Republic of Ireland county, Donegal, to the west.

place_439.name: Islands in the South Seas
place_439.description: The South Sea Islands are located in the south west Pacific Ocean.

place_025.name: Stockbridge
place_025.description: Stockbridge is a town in Hampshire.

place_305.name: Bedfordshire
place_305.description: A county in the east of England. The county town is Bedford.

place_026.name: Loch Ness
place_026.description: Loch Ness is a large freshwater loch in the Scottish Highlands.

place_027.name: Hampshire
place_027.description: Hampshire is a county in southern England.

place_029.name: Newbury, Berkshire
place_029.description: Newbury is a market town in the county of Berkshire, England.

place_031.name: Woburn
place_031.description: Davy mentions Priestley Bog and meadow near Woburn in Elements of Agricultural Chemistry p. 265.

place_306.name: Alston Moor
place_306.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

place_307.name: Mendip District
place_307.description: A range of limestone hills to the south of Bristol and Bath in Somerset, England.

place_308.name: Gloucestershire
place_308.description: A county in the west of England. The county town is Gloucester.

place_319.name: Brecknockshire
place_319.description: Also known as the County of Brecknock, Breconshire, or the County of Brecon. One of thirteen historic counties of Wales. The county town is Brecon.

place_320.name: Norfolk
place_320.description: A county in the east of England. The largest settlement is Norwich.

place_321.name: Cheshire
place_321.description: A county in north-western England. The county town is Chester.

place_322.name: Merionethshire
place_322.description: A county in northern Wales. One of thirteen historic counties of Wales. The county town was Dolgellau.

place_440.name: Darling Downs
place_440.description: The South Downs are a range of chalk hills extending from Hampshire to Sussex.

place_441.name: Marsh Gibbon
place_441.description: Stowey is a village in Somerset with nearby marshland, parts of which are now areas of conservation.

place_1029.name: Durham, England
place_1029.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

place_323.name: Cambridge
place_323.description: Cambridge is the county town of Cambridgeshire.

otherwork_260.author: John Woodward

otherwork_032.author: Smithson Tennant

otherwork_064.name: A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts

otherwork_261.name: The Principles of Agriculture and Vegetation

otherwork_063.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London

otherwork_090.name: Phytologia; or; The Philosophy of Agriculture and Gardening

otherwork_091.name: A General Treatise of Husbandry and Gardening
otherwork_091.author: Richard Bradley

otherwork_088.name: Essay, in Answer to the Following Question Proposed by the Royal Irish Academy: ̀̀what are the Manures most advantageously applicable to the various sorts of Soils, and what are the Causes of their beneficial Effect in each particular Instance?''
otherwork_088.author: Richard Kirwan

otherwork_026.name: Annals of Agriculture and Other Useful Arts
otherwork_026.author: Arthur Young

otherwork_072.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
